content.description: Climbs the faint crack line left of the more obvious "North Country Crack".  The crux is pulling up and past the major horizontal via a nice but maybe a bit insecure side-pull and then long reach to secret hold and a cross-over move all with the gear at your feet.  The more broken rock above the crux is sustained 5.8.
content.protection: Medium cams and wired stoppers. In the horizontal to protect the crux place a couple of a couple #2-3 C4 sized cams and equalize them.
content.location: The distinct line just left of "North Country Crack" at the North Woods area, West Bluff.

content.description:
A sweet looking vertical crack ... but on closer inspection it's pretty short and often within reach of the easier line to the left. 

  Still, if you are a Devils Lake local you are accustomed to gently focusing your mind on the holds immediately in front of you, and letting the rest of the world drift away.  There are some good moves here.
content.protection: A couple of finger-sized nuts and cams.
content.location: Around one more corner to the South from "North Country Crack".

content.description:
Start in the crack and follow it up and slightly left. The top has little to no protection.  

  Either set an anchor before hand or finish to the right.  

  Ends in same place as North country corner and the slot.
content.location: Around the corner of North country corner.

content.description: #9 in the Climber's Guide. Start on small ledge and follow wide diagonal crack 3-4 feet left of the corner.
content.protection: Spots to build an anchor for top-rope, looks like good pro for trad

content.description: The obvious arete right of Divergent Crack.  It's labeled route #4 in the new Swartling/Mayer guide.   The description in this guide is accurate but I think the difficulty is a bit under-rated and especially if one attempts to stay strictly on the left side of the arete and doesn't reach over right around the corner (maybe mid 5.11?).  If one climbs the arete straight on utilizing holds left and right it's possibly 5.9.  If one traverses around the corner after making the initial moves up and off the block then utilizing the projecting horn then its 5.6 to 5.7.  Finish this variation by stepping back left after avoiding and getting above the hard strict arete moves.  I ended up on-sighting the easier variation on lead but worked the arete itself on TR.  This thing is short and really just a protectable boulder problem but to boulder it  only would be nasty in the landing (big pointy rotten tree stump).  It's a fun and worth the effort route I think.
content.protection: Small to medium cams, small to medium wires.  Next to smallest C3 to protect the last moves up the Slap Arete (shallow vertical fissure before blank rock on arete's left side).
content.location: North Slope- West Bluff #4 in latest guide but is un-named..  Thought I would give it one..

content.description: Sven says "Climb slightly overhanging ledges on or near corner". There's one stopper move where I had to dead-point for a sloping ledge, hence the rating bump from the guidebook.
content.protection: TR, I didn't look at gear.
content.location: Arete right of North Country Crack.

content.description:
A clearly defined vertical crack system that just begs you to scramble up! 

  The crux might be getting off the ground.  Higher up you contend with an off-fingers sized crack, and footholds that disappear under little bulges.
content.protection:
Gear to 1.5". 

  After the first ten or fifteen feet you can get great gear at less-than-body-length intervals (even if you are very short).
content.location: This is on the south side of the "third buttress" (counting from the North).

content.description: #8 in the Climber's Guide. Start on left leaning corner to small overhang and continue left while staying on the corner the top.
content.protection: Spots to build an anchor for top-rope, looks like good pro for trad

content.description: A tricky slab utilizing a dual crack system.
content.location: When facing North Country Crack turnaround and go down and then around a corner to the right. Also listed in Sven's book.

content.description: Look for a wall below the weakness in the upper face. Follow the crack as it goes up and to the right.
content.location: Fifth route as you come around the corner from the West Bluff trail (break from the trail left 125 yards south of the north end of West Bluff Trail).

content.description: Follow the wide crack up to the block party and finish at the big tree.
content.location: To the left of Sore Toes. Number 22 in the devils lake guide book 3rd edition.

content.description:
Although this area has one of the shortest approaches at the Lake, it has also been underdocumented until the publication of the 3rd edition of the "Climber's Guide to Devil's Lake".  Even now, several of the best routes here remain unnamed and therefore unknown to most local climbers! 

  I think the best lines here are likely to be "North Country Crack" (5.7), "Down South" (5.9), and "Divergent Crack" (5.10).
